awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Study of Niobium Tungsten Oxide Anodes for High-Performance Aqueous Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern human society requires efficient, affordable and safe means for energy storage. Today, rechargeable lithium–ion batteries dominate the energy storage landscape from portable electronics to the rapidly expanding electric vehicles and electricity (grid) storage applications. However, current lithium-ion batteries suffer from safety and cost issues, primarily because of flammable, moisture-sensitive and expensive organic solvents used in the electrolytes. This project is aimed at replacing the organic solvent electrolyte with water, in a manner that does not compromise on battery performance (i.e., volumetric and gravimetric energy and power density). To accomplish this, the research team proposes to explore new classes of complex oxide (niobium tungsten oxide) materials that will be designed specifically for aqueous battery chemistries, enabling breakthrough improvements in volumetric energy and power density for the next generation of aqueous batteries. This work will contribute to low-cost, high-performance and safe aqueous batteries that are critical for large-scale energy storage.    

A number of fundamental science and engineering issues will be addressed in this project in order to enable the successful development of aqueous lithium-ion batteries with niobium tungsten oxide anodes. These include: (1) Benchmarking the chemical stability of niobium tungsten oxide anodes in aqueous (water-in-salt) electrolytes and establishing whether a protective coating is needed to improve stability; (2) Developing an in-depth understanding of aqueous electrolyte lithiation and delithation mechanism(s) in niobium tungsten oxide anodes; (3) Studying the interfacial chemistry and solid electrolyte interface that develops during battery operation; and (4) Compositional engineering (i.e., alloying and doping) of niobium tungsten oxide compounds to improve their gravimetric and rate performance. In this project, each of the above tasks will be addressed using a coupled experimental and computational approach, so that a deep and in-depth fundamental understanding of the underlying science can be achieved. Success will be assessed by an ability to optimize the niobium tungsten oxide composition and increase the operating voltage window of the aqueous battery, leading to a substantial increase in volumetric and gravimetric energy density. Success will also be determined by the team’s ability to enhance the high-rate performance of niobium tungsten oxides in an aqueous setting, leading to significant improvement in fast charging capability. Finally, the niobium tungsten oxide electrodes will be optimized and engineered to cycle in a stable and safe manner over thousands of charge-discharge steps with high coulombic efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
The world is transitioning towards sustainable energy solutions, with batteries playing a critical role in this shift. However, current battery technologies, such as lithium-ion batteries, face significant challenges, including limited raw material availability, high costs, and environmental concerns. This research aimed to address these issues by exploring alternative battery materials, particularly niobium tungsten oxides (NTO), and evaluating their potential for safer, cost-effective aqueous battery systems.

Key Achievements:

1.     Understanding New Battery Materials:
The project investigated the unique properties of niobium tungsten oxides, which are promising candidates for next-generation batteries. These materials feature open-tunnel structures that facilitate efficient ion movement, making them ideal for fast-charging and high-performance applications.

2.     Leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI):
Advanced AI tools, including generative models and machine learning algorithms, were employed to discover and design new materials. These techniques enabled researchers to efficiently explore and validate potential materials across vast chemical spaces, significantly reducing time and resource requirements compared to traditional trial-and-error approaches.

3.     Sustainability and Accessibility:
By prioritizing abundant elements like calcium and aluminum over scarce lithium, the research supports the development of more sustainable and affordable battery solutions. This innovation could make clean energy accessible to a broader range of communities worldwide.

4.     Collaborative and Educational Efforts:
The project fostered collaborations between institutions and provided training opportunities for students, including high school interns, in advanced technologies like computational modeling and AI. These efforts equip the next generation to address future energy challenges.

Why It Matters:

The findings of this research have far-reaching implications. Developing safer and more affordable batteries has the potential to revolutionize energy storage, making renewable sources like solar and wind power more practical for everyday use. Reducing dependence on scarce resources like lithium not only lowers costs but also minimizes environmental harm and supports ethical practices in resource extraction.

This project highlights the transformative potential of interdisciplinary research, combining materials science, artificial intelligence, and sustainable practices to tackle critical energy challenges. By advancing battery technology, it lays the foundation for a cleaner, more equitable, and energy-secure future.

Outcomes and Impact:

Throughout the project, we collaborated extensively with experimental partners at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI). Our work resulted in three publications in leading journals: Energy Advances (2024, Cover Article), Journal of Materials Science (2023), and Journal of Materials (2024). An additional paper is in press in Cell Reports Physical Science.

This project fully supported one Ph.D. student, Mr. Joy Datta, who is expected to graduate in Summer 2025, and partially supported another Ph.D. student, Ms. Rumana Hasan (currently in third year). The collaboration between computational and experimental approaches was a hallmark of the project, offering a unique intellectual perspective and bringing oxide materials closer to commercialization.

In the long term, the scientific achievements from this research could revolutionize the secondary battery industry, including applications in electric vehicles (EVs). The scientific knowledge developed during the project has been integrated into several undergraduate and graduate courses taught by Dr. Datta at NJIT.

Additionally, the project produced a substantial dataset of atomistic simulations for various interface systems, which will facilitate the development of machine learning potentials. The machine learning code developed during this study has been made freely available on GitHub.

Considering both computational advancements and commercial applications, this project has significantly contributed to enhancing the competitiveness of U.S.-based battery manufacturing.

 

 


 


Last Modified: 12/29/2024
Modified by: Dibakar Datta
